keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump's announcement of a $100,000 fee on H-1B visas.
The H-1B visa program allows U.S. companies to hire skilled foreign workers and has been critical for tech and retail sectors like Walmart.
Walmart currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders and is one of the largest employers of such workers in the private sector.
The new visa fee is intended by the Trump administration to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program, but it may significantly increase costs and deter hiring for U.S. companies.
The policy change disproportionately affects skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants.
This shift signals a broader trend where major U.S. businesses are adjusting hiring strategies in response to stricter immigration policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., has paused job offers to foreign workers requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on these high-skilled work visas. This policy shift reflects growing corporate sensitivity to the Trump administration’s immigration agenda, which aims to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program. The move disproportionately impacts skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants. While Walmart maintains that it is committed to hiring top talent, the change signals broader economic and strategic consequences for U.S. businesses reliant on foreign technical talent, especially in competitive sectors like e-commerce.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
